info.author: Templarbit Inc.
info.description:
Django-templarbit
=================

Requirements
------------

-  Python 2.7 or 3.4+
-  A supported version of Django (currently 1.8+)
-  Your Templarbit Property ID and API Key. Sign up at
   https://templarbit.com/ to get these

Installation
------------

To install ``django-templarbit`` simply run:

::

    $ pip install django-templarbit

Configuration
-------------

We need to hook ``django-templarbit`` into our project.
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

Put ``templarbit`` into your ``INSTALLED_APPS`` at settings module:

.. code:: python


    INSTALLED_APPS = (
     '...',
     'templarbit',
    )

Add templarbit middleware to your ``settings.py``. The closer the
``TemplarbitMiddleware`` is to the top of your middleware list the
better:

.. code:: python


    MIDDLEWARE = (
        'templarbit.middleware.TemplarbitMiddleware',
        '...',
    )

Add the Templarbit configuration environment variables to your project:

*Note: This keeps the secret keys out of your source control!*

Linux:

.. code:: bash

        $ export TEMPLARBIT_PROPERTY_ID='some_awesome_property_id'
        $ export TEMPLARBIT_API_TOKEN='some_great_api_token'

Heroku:

.. code:: bash

        $ heroku config:set TEMPLARBIT_PROPERTY_ID='some_awesome_property_id'
        $ heroku config:set TEMPLARBIT_API_TOKEN='some_great_api_token'

That's all!
-----------

You're done. Now every request made to your django application is
protected by Templarbit

To check your installation, you can examine the response headers from
your application:

.. code:: bash

    $ curl -v http://127.0.0.1:8000/
    * Connected to 127.0.0.1 (127.0.0.1) port 8000 (#0)
    > GET / HTTP/1.1
    > Host: 127.0.0.1:8000
    > User-Agent: curl/7.47.0
    > Accept: */*
    > 
    * HTTP 1.0, assume close after body
    < HTTP/1.0 200 OK
    < Date: Mon, 28 Aug 2017 04:22:34 GMT
    < Server: WSGIServer/0.1 Python/2.7.12
    < Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only: default-src 'self'; script-src 'self'; object-src 'self'; base-uri 'none'; report-uri https://logs.templarbit.com/csp/aoeu123-3bf5/reports;
    < X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN
    < Content-Type: application/json
    < Content-Length: 18
    < Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'; script-src 'self'; object-src 'self'; base-uri 'none'; report-uri https://logs.templarbit.com/csp/aoeuaoeu123-3bf5/reports;
    < 
    * Closing connection 0

Notice the ``Content-Security-Policy`` pulled from Templarbit
info.name: django-templarbit
info.summary: Templarbit protects Django applications from XSS attacks and other malicious activity.
